content:
I'm watching Lurie's lectures on TQFTs and around the 14m30s mark, he says that HomBund1(∅,∅)\text{Hom}_{\text{Bund}_1}(\emptyset, \emptyset)HomBund1​​(∅,∅) is the "classifying space for 1-manifolds" (with empty boundary). In particular it has connected components corresponding to some number of circles.

When we look at the component for a single circle, to me it seems like we should get BDiff+(S1)B\text{Diff}^+(S^1)BDiff+(S1), but Lurie says that we get the classifying space for circle bundles, CP∞\mathbb{CP}^\inftyCP∞. He does also say a few seconds later that he means BDiff+(S1)B\text{Diff}^+(S^1)BDiff+(S1), but it's not obvious to me that these are the same space.

Should it be obvious? Maybe they're merely homotopy equivalent? Is it true more generally that BDiff(F)B\text{Diff}(F)BDiff(F) should classify bundles with fibre FFF?

Thanks for the help! ^_^
Something like: Diff(S1)=O(2)Diff(S^1) = O(2)Diff(S1)=O(2), so BDiff(S1)=BO(2)BDiff(S^1) = BO(2)BDiff(S1)=BO(2). Then BO(2)=BU(1)=  CP∞BO(2) = BU(1) =  \mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{\infty}BO(2)=BU(1)=  CP∞.

Hi David! Diff(S1)≃O(2)\mathrm{Diff}(S^1) \simeq \mathrm{O}(2)Diff(S1)≃O(2), but O(2)≆U(1)\mathrm{O}(2) \ncong \mathrm{U}(1)O(2)≆U(1) so this argument needs to patched a little. In fact O(2)≅U(1)×Z/2\mathrm{O}(2) \cong \mathrm{U}(1) \times \mathbb{Z}/2O(2)≅U(1)×Z/2 where the two components correspond to orientation-preserving and orientation-reversing rotations.

But notice Lurie mentioned Diff+(S1)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1)Diff+(S1), the topological group of orientation-preserving diffeomorphisms of the circle. We have Diff+(S1)≃SO(2)≅U(1)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1) \simeq \mathrm{SO}(2) \cong \mathrm{U(1)}Diff+(S1)≃SO(2)≅U(1) and then yes, BU(1)≃CP∞\mathrm{BU}(1) \simeq \mathbb{CP}^\inftyBU(1)≃CP∞.

It may seem trivial that Diff+(S1)≃SO(2)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1) \simeq \text{SO}(2)Diff+(S1)≃SO(2), but this is a bit stronger than just saying every orientation-preserving diffeomorphism of the circle is smoothly homotopic to a rotation: it's saying we can do that homotopy in a kind of 'uniform' way.

It's a lot harder to show Diff+(S2)≃SO(3)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^2) \simeq \text{SO}(3)Diff+(S2)≃SO(3). For some reason I was interested in these things once, and a proof is section 7.3 of Kuipers' Lectures on Diffeomorphism Groups of Manifolds

But then things get really hard. There are 'weird' diffeomorphisms of the nnn-sphere, and gluing together two (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-balls along their boundary using such a weird diffeomorphism you can get an exotic (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-sphere: one that's homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic to the usual (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-sphere. For example, Diff+(S6)\mathsf{Diff}^+(S^6)Diff+(S6) has 28 connected components, corresponding to the 28 exotic 7-spheres. So we can't have Diff+(S6)≃SO(7)\mathsf{Diff}^+(S^6) \simeq \mathrm{SO}(7)Diff+(S6)≃SO(7), since SO(n)\mathrm{SO}(n)SO(n) always has just one connected component!

Smale and Cerf showed that for n≥6n \ge 6n≥6, π0(Diff+(Sn))\pi_0(\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^n))π0​(Diff+(Sn)) is isomorphic to the group of (orientation-preserving diffeomorphism classes of) exotic (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-spheres. The first interesting case is

π0(Diff+(S6))≅Z/28\pi_0(\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^6)) \cong \mathbb{Z}/28π0​(Diff+(S6))≅Z/28

But this is really hard math, and I'm just reporting results that I don't understand.
So be glad Lurie was working with the lowly 1-sphere, @Chris Grossack (they/them)!

1. This is all extremely interesting! And the fact that nobody has quickly told me why BDiff(F) should classify F-bundles also makes me feel better that maybe Lurie misspoke quickly (or more likely, that maybe I misunderstood what he said) and in fact this is all something special about S1S^1S1.
Though there is some evidence for the more general claim. For instance, see Andy Putman's comments on this MO post, or the Theorem 6.2 in Christensen and Wu's Smooth Classifying Spaces

John Baez said:

It may seem trivial that Diff+(S1)≃SO(2)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1) \simeq \text{SO}(2)Diff+(S1)≃SO(2), but this is a bit stronger than just saying every orientation-preserving diffeomorphism of the circle is smoothly homotopic to a rotation: it's saying we can do that homotopy in a kind of 'uniform' way.

In particular, every oriented diffeomorphism of the circle is smoothly homotopy to a point, so there's something interesting to show!

Is it just me, or is the evaluation-at-1 map Diff+(S1)→S1\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1)\to S^1Diff+(S1)→S1 actually a trivial fiber bundle, whose fiber is the group of orientation-preserving diffeos of the circle which fix 111? This latter group has a pretty explicit contraction if you view it as the space of increasing (smooth) bijections [0,1]→[0,1][0,1]\to [0,1][0,1]→[0,1], which gives the result. In fact, I guess it doesn't matter whether the bundle is trivial--any bundle with contractible fibers is homotopy equivalent to the base!

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

  1. This is all extremely interesting! And the fact that nobody has quickly told me why BDiff(F) should classify F-bundles also makes me feel better that maybe Lurie misspoke quickly (or more likely, that maybe I misunderstood what he said) and in fact this is all something special about S1S^1S1.

I do think it's generally true that BDiff(F)B\mathrm{Diff}(F)BDiff(F) is the classifying space for bundles with fiber FFF for FFF a smooth manifold. One way of constructing BDiff(F)B\mathrm{Diff}(F)BDiff(F) is as the quotient of the space of embeddings of FFF in R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ by its action of Diff(F),\mathrm{Diff}(F),Diff(F), since the space of embeddings is contractible (the space of maps into R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ is contractible since R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ is, and there's lots of room to wiggle any non-embedding of FFF or of F×IF\times IF×I a tiny bit to get an embedding.) Thus a map M→BDiff(F)M\to B\mathrm{Diff}(F)M→BDiff(F) is a smooth choice of subspace of R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ diffeomorphic to FFF for every point of m.m.m. At least if MMM is itself a manifold, then any FFF-bundle over MMM will be too, and so you can embed the whole bundle into R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ (again, uniquely up to contractible choice), which gives a map from FFF-bundles over MMM to [M,BDiff(F)].[M,B\mathrm{Diff}(F)].[M,BDiff(F)]. This isn't a proof but I think it's the vibe Lurie was hoping you'd have.

An even more core way of stating the vibe is that BDiff(F)B\mathrm{Diff}(F)BDiff(F) is "the space of all possible copies of FFF, up to diffeomorphisms." It's just that there's no actual universal space in which all copies of FFF live, so we pick R∞\mathbb R^\inftyR∞ as a sufficiently-universal space if FFF is a smooth manifold insofar exactly as we get the contractible embedding space; any other universal space with that property also works.

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

  1. This is all extremely interesting! And the fact that nobody has quickly told me why BDiff(F) should classify F-bundles also makes me feel better that maybe Lurie misspoke quickly (or more likely, that maybe I misunderstood what he said) and in fact this is all something special about S1S^1S1.

What do you mean by an F-bundle? If you mean a bundle where all the fibers are diffeomorphic to F and we glue together the bundle from trivial F-bundles using continuous Diff(F)-valued cocycles on the overlaps Uα∩UβU_\alpha \cap U_\betaUα​∩Uβ​ of some good cover of the base space, it's more or less an automatic consequence of general results about classifying spaces that F-bundles are classified by BDiff(F)... well, at least F-bundles over a paracompact base space! (There is some annoying technical dirt like that in the general theory of classifying spaces, at least the old stuff I know.)

If we want the diffeomorphisms to be smooth cocycles (as is natural in differential topology) there may be extra things to check.

But even so - if that's all we wanted, we'd be studying circle bundles where the fibers are mere manifolds, not U(1)\mathrm{U}(1)U(1)-torsors. If we're trying to classify principal U(1)\mathrm{U}(1)U(1) bundles, which are much more rigid, we should be using BU(1)B\mathrm{U}(1)BU(1). So then we run into the question of how BDiff(S1)B\mathrm{Diff}(S^1)BDiff(S1) is related to BU(1)≅BSO(2)B\mathrm{U}(1) \cong B\mathrm{SO}(2)BU(1)≅BSO(2). And then we wind up wanting to know

Diff+(S1)≃SO(2) \mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1) \simeq \mathrm{SO}(2)Diff+(S1)≃SO(2)

which is a very special fact (since the analogous fact doesn't hold for spheres of every dimension).

Once you believe in this vibe, then no matter what kind of a thing FFF is you might believe that maps X→BAuto(F)X\to B\mathrm{Auto}(F)X→BAuto(F) are FFF-bundles in whatever category Auto(F)\mathrm{Auto}(F)Auto(F) comes from are going to be maps from XXX into the "space of all possible copies of FFF up to automorphisms", and then if you define such maps to be bundles with fiber FFF then you can just try to apply a representability theorem to define that space of all possible FFF s as BAuto(F)B\mathrm{Auto}(F)BAuto(F), without futzing with any universal embedding space for F.F.F. You can actually do this in an appropriate context with Brown representability, if you didn't know.

Kevin Carlson said:

Is it just me, or is the evaluation-at-1 map Diff+(S1)→S1\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1)\to S^1Diff+(S1)→S1 actually a trivial fiber bundle, whose fiber is the group of orientation-preserving diffeos of the circle which fix 111?

How are you getting the trivialization? Let's see. I'll treat S1S^1S1 as a subgroup of Diff+(S1)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1)Diff+(S1) in the obvious way: it consists of rotations of the circle.

Then I'll try to write any diffeomorphism f:S1→S1f: S^1 \to S^1f:S1→S1 as g:S1→S1g: S^1 \to S^1g:S1→S1 times h:S1→S1h: S^1 \to S^1h:S1→S1 where ggg is the rotation that maps 1∈S11 \in S^11∈S1 to f(1)f(1)f(1), and hhh is an orientation-preserving diffeomorphism that fixes 111.

Is that the idea?

(By "times" I might mean composition in the diffeomorphism group, or I might mean "pointwise times" using the fact that S1S^1S1 is a group. I also refuse to say which in which order I'm multiplying ggg and hhh, on the grounds that it might incriminate me.)

This latter group has a pretty explicit contraction if you view it as the space of increasing (smooth) bijections [0,1]→[0,1][0,1]\to [0,1][0,1]→[0,1], which gives the result.

Okay. Yes, I vaguely recall that the result is roughly this hard: nothing mind-boggling. As we start studying higher-dimensional spheres the study of Diff+(Sn)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^n)Diff+(Sn) quickly becomes much harder, reaching a maximum around the scary dimensions n=3,4n = 3, 4n=3,4 and then turning into a bunch of homotopy-theoretic calculations connected to algebraic K-theory.

In fact, I guess it doesn't matter whether the bundle is trivial--any bundle with contractible fibers is homotopy equivalent to the base!

Okay, all that work I did for nothing.

John Baez said:

Is that the idea?

Yeah, something like that. What I was specifically thinking is that the fiber over eiθe^{i\theta}eiθ is naturally identified with the smooth strictly increasing self-bijections of [eiθ,eiθ+2π],[e^{i\theta},e^{i\theta}+2\pi],[eiθ,eiθ+2π], so the trivialization just adds eiθe^{i\theta}eiθ to the input and output of a self-map of [0,2π].[0,2\pi].[0,2π]. So, multiplying by that rotation, yeah.
Okay, good. By the way, there's something funky about your use of quotes here. (It's always a pain dealing with quotes here.)
Thanks, that should do it.

Iiiiii see. The point is that if you believe there's a contractible space of Fs, then you end up with BAut(F)=⋆/Aut(F)B\text{Aut}(F) = \star \big / \text{Aut}(F)BAut(F)=⋆/Aut(F) being the space of Fs up to automorphism.
Thanks!

Yeah, that's the easy beautiful conceptual part. The fun particular part is showing the topological group Diff+(S1)\mathrm{Diff}^+(S^1)Diff+(S1) is equivalent as an ∞\infty∞-group to the circle! So that's what Kevin showed.

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

Iiiiii see. The point is that if you believe there's a contractible space of Fs, then you end up with BAut(F)=⋆/Aut(F)B\text{Aut}(F) = \star \big / \text{Aut}(F)BAut(F)=⋆/Aut(F) being the space of Fs up to automorphism.

Specifically a contractible space of FFF s on which the automorphism group acts freely, eg you can’t just take a point.
You can just take a point if by "///" you mean a homotopy quotient.
Terminologically, I would say that BAut(F)B \mathrm{Aut}(F)BAut(F) is "the space of FFF s".

Have people developed enough 'cohesive homotopy type theory' (or whatever they call it) so we can easily do things like study the de Rham cohomology of BAut(F)B \mathrm{Aut}(F) BAut(F) when FFF is a Riemannian manifold - so if FFF is the round (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-sphere, Aut(F)=O(n)\mathrm{Aut}(F) = \mathrm{O}(n)Aut(F)=O(n) and BAut(F)B \mathrm{Aut}(F)BAut(F) is a smooth model of BO(n)B\mathrm{O}(n)BO(n)? I'd like to make it not hard to show BO(n)B\mathrm{O}(n)BO(n) is "equal" to the space of nnn-dimensional linear subspaces of an infinite-dimensional Hilbert space, or something like that.
I can do all this stuff using ordinary math, but it's a bit onerous at certain points, and I can imagine it becoming easier.
